contents.title: lift up connections
contents.description_html: kind of curious about an idea i had looking at one of the groves visualization prototypes - i wanted really badly to "lift up" the selected block and all the ones it's related to, almost like on a unique plane, to manipulate them all somehow as a group. Maybe it could just be moving them all to one area of the canvas, but maybe it can also become an efficient "fuzzy selection" mechanism for selecting sort of fuzzy-edged groupings of related content

contents.title: the question of hierarchy in groves pt. 1
contents.generated_title: the question of hierarchy in groves pt. 1
contents.content_html:
right now: the question of hierarchy. do we need it, and how could it work? i think we're trained to like structure, like a filesystem, but i reckon a large part of a person's thinking does not naturally operate this way. we jump from this thing to that more frequently than we realize, and even the categories we use to group the things we think about are relative according to the object of one's thought at a given moment. this is in a sense why people can hold many opposing views at one time, all reconciled within that person's understanding of the world.

but still, our relational thinking contains implicit structures that allow us to understand things within our own universe of concepts (i.e. one's personal canon). when i express an idea to someone, i'm not just expressing that discrete idea. it's more like i'm evoking a big mesh of other ideas that intersect at the one i'm expressing. for example: when i talk about my book, i'm evoking a strange chain of related ideas that culminated in my final theses; those connections are what, for me, create the meaning i'm trying to communicate. it follows, then, that a good tool for thinking should include an interconnected, and de-centered, database, visualized in a number of discrete hierarchical and non-hierarchical ways.

it seems like a lot of software, regardless of what it's for, doesn't like for this to happen — we're meant to view things one way, with relationships that are centered on a single object in a system, and where those definitions are essentially immutable. open notion and evernote and are.na, and you'll find decreasingly centralized notions of information structure. on one end of that spectrum you'll find a data structure that can be "reshaped" in presentation, but always maintains a certain hierarchical structure consisting of bits of information that you "define" by giving them titles and attribute. there's some useful stuff there. on the other end, you'll find a loosely defined concept of "channels" that assemble bits of information together, presumably under a central concept — there's an implicit hierarchy, but connections don't necessarily entail a notion of inheritance. there's useful stuff there, too.

the question then is how to allow for both cases — strict hierarchy in some cases, and loose association in others.

title: ✎ A Higher Bar for Design Tooling

metadata.description: Research and process for a (hopefully medium-length) essay about the low bar for quality we've come to expect from design tools, and what things we should be expecting instead.

contents.content_html:
It's very likely that many of the limitations we feel day-to-day in our design tools are limitations of the existing canvas and layer model.

In my work at Palantir I helped conceive and develop and very robust, strongly typed layer model that takes the burden of organization and labeling off a user's back. This meant that users could focus on data analysis and intuitive thinking rather than on organizational overhead.

We also used a canvas-like model — granted, it was a world map, not a blank white canvas — to display these layers. The interactions afforded in our canvas model were astoundingly robust, giving users superpowers to analyze and work with layers on their map.

Why don't we have equally robust functionality for working with layers in professional product tools?
contents.content:
It's very likely that many of the limitations we feel day-to-day in our design tools are limitations of the existing canvas and layer model.

In my work at Palantir I helped conceive and develop and very robust, strongly typed layer model that takes the burden of organization and labeling off a user's back. This meant that users could focus on data analysis and intuitive thinking rather than on organizational overhead.

We also used a canvas-like model — granted, it was a world map, not a blank white canvas — to display these layers. The interactions afforded in our canvas model were astoundingly robust, giving users superpowers to analyze and work with layers on their map.

Why don't we have equally robust functionality for working with layers in professional product tools?

contents.content_html:
Another thing to note about product design tools today is that their layer and canvas models are based on a combination of things from Adobe Illustrator.

They inherited Illustrator's model of an infinite canvas with fixed-point coordinates and fixed elements with very basic z-indexing. They also inherited Illustrator's very problematic "loose" layer model, which is to say, they are operating with mostly unmodeled layer constructs.

This has a lot of ramifications because these applications are entirely layer-driven. My primary problems with the model they're using is that it doesn't have enough rules to enforce good standards of organization and collaboration, and the canvas model makes it damn near impossible to create autolayouts and flexible or responsive components

contents.title: About - Devin Halladay
contents.description_html: I'm a designer working across all media past, present, and future, to understand, conceptualize, and implement systems and infrastructures at every scale. My design practice interrogates the politics and ideology articulated through the acts and artifacts of design. I believe that aesthetics are the synthesis of ideology and form, and that form itself is political.

title: LSD and the search for pure immanence

metadata.description: what can psychedelics and psychedelic aesthetics teach us about our baseline phenomenology and dominant (western, capitalist, christian) ontology?

contents.content_html:
great trip yesterday, will post more later, but i wasn't able to dig into immanence much. there were some realizations and a few things deleuze et. al (esp benjamin and heidegger) were getting at in their own ways began to concretize in my head.

mostly it was an introspective trip + spent a lot of time in the park just enjoying watching things happen around me, which i guess is in itself immanence in a small way

contents.content_html:
Quotes from The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead

“Of course, the drug dose does not produce the transcendent experience. It merely acts as a chemical key - it opens the mind, frees the nervous system of its ordinary patterns and structures. The nature of the experience depends almost entirely on set and setting. Set denotes the preparation of the individual, including his personality structure and his mood at the time. Setting is physical - the weather, the room's atmosphere; social - feelings of persons present towards one another; and cultural - prevailing views as to what is real. It is for this reason that manuals or guide-books are necessary. Their purpose is to enable a person to understand the new realities of the expanded consciousness, to serve as road maps for new interior territories which modern science has made accessible.”
contents.content:
### Quotes from *The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead*

> “Of course, the drug dose does not produce the transcendent experience. It merely acts as a chemical key - it opens the mind, frees the nervous system of its ordinary patterns and structures. The nature of the experience depends almost entirely on set and setting. Set denotes the preparation of the individual, including his personality structure and his mood at the time. Setting is physical - the weather, the room's atmosphere; social - feelings of persons present towards one another; and cultural - prevailing views as to what is real. It is for this reason that manuals or guide-books are necessary. Their purpose is to enable a person to understand the new realities of the expanded consciousness, to serve as road maps for new interior territories which modern science has made accessible.”

contents.title: a manual based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead; The Psychedelic Handbook
contents.generated_title: a manual based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead; The Psychedelic Handbook

contents.content_html: D&G it seems thought drugs to be antithetical to the base ideology of the plane of immanence — loopholes that allow us to glimpse immateriality but not become immaterial ourselves (pure immanence). I'm not so sure about this. I think they've missed the aesthetic side of psychedelics completely — the ontology revealed through their use can speak volumes not only to the cracks and fissures in the world but also to the sensibilities that can heal those fissures. A shortcut? Maybe. Antithetical? I don't think so.

contents.content_html:
Quotes from The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead

“Of course, the drug dose does not produce the transcendent experience. It merely acts as a chemical key - it opens the mind, frees the nervous system of its ordinary patterns and structures. The nature of the experience depends almost entirely on set and setting. Set denotes the preparation of the individual, including his personality structure and his mood at the time. Setting is physical - the weather, the room's atmosphere; social - feelings of persons present towards one another; and cultural - prevailing views as to what is real. It is for this reason that manuals or guide-books are necessary. Their purpose is to enable a person to understand the new realities of the expanded consciousness, to serve as road maps for new interior territories which modern science has made accessible.”

contents.content_html: D&G it seems thought drugs to be antithetical to the base ideology of the plane of immanence — loopholes that allow us to glimpse immateriality but not become immaterial ourselves (pure immanence). I'm not so sure about this. I think they've missed the aesthetic side of psychedelics completely — the ontology revealed through their use can speak volumes not only to the cracks and fissures in the world but also to the sensibilities that can heal those fissures. A shortcut? Maybe. Antithetical? I don't think so.

metadata.description: learning about sustainability in all senses, primarily in terms of the environment but also in terms of the health and maintenance of systems in general.

What is Sustainable Graphic Design? In Flourishing, John Ehrenfeld writes that “The key to doing something about sustainability is that you first have to say what it is that you want to sustain.” So, to define sustainable graphic design then we first must define what it is we are sustaining. Sustainable graphic design is design in service of what you want to sustain. Ehrenfeld wants to sustain “that all humans and other life should flourish.” Bruce Mau described "Massive Change" similarly: “Our project is the welfare of all life.” Sustainable graphic design is then perhaps best defined as “graphic design in support of all life flourishing.” Sustainable Graphic Design is thus very different than status quo design. "All life flourishing" is not the traditional goal of business, culture, and design. Sustainable graphic design doesn’t solely rely on better materials or more socially conscious manufacturing. If sustainable graphic design is different than regular design, it requires different ways of thinking and making. Sustainable graphic design should also potentially carry with it different styles/aesthetics/outcomes. (All design is ideological, how some looks reflects what ideologies it promotes, etc.)
Sustainable Graphic Design. Runs once every year or two. GD314

metadata.description: test stuff for a vague effort to build a tool on top of are.na that adds better metadata like tags to filter on and connect between. basically wondering "what if are.na had an ontology?"

contents.content_html:
some approaches:
- if are.na can implement an api endpoint for getting comments from a block, the logic could be: any comment by the block's author is a piece of metadata in a json- or yaml-like format, or maybe some data structure where you have key: value and then can also write key2: key//value2 or something similar; basically a simple syntax for 1) adding a single metadata key, and 2) using metadata keys INSIDE other metadata keys' values so you can build nested data structures
- hm, if that can't work, I think I could do the same thing with block description and/or block title

The center supports work through project design and development, publications, faculty and student fellowships, and global education initiatives.

contents.content_html:
[WIP] Futures of Journalism Rules of Engagement

  1. Stop going to media & journalism conferences

  2. Listen to non-media folks talking about journalism

  3. Search for the unknown unknowns

  4. Speculate and publish your speculations

  5. Build something and break it

  6. Learn about the history of journalism

  7. Question your notions of how journalism works and has to function

  8. Ask "what if not?"

  9. Question the tech-centered visions of the future of media and journalism
contents.content:
[WIP] Futures of Journalism Rules of Engagement

1. Stop going to media & journalism conferences

2. Listen to non-media folks talking about journalism

3. Search for the unknown unknowns

4. Speculate and publish your speculations

5. Build something and break it

6. Learn about the history of journalism

7. Question your notions of how journalism works and has to function

8. Ask "what if not?"

9. Question the tech-centered visions of the future of media and journalism

contents.content_html: "Infrastructure and ideology are not so different at all."
contents.content: "Infrastructure and ideology are not so different at all."

contents.content_html:
I want access to the real. Unmediated experience. Augmentation is fine so long as it does not obscure my access to the real. Models and representations are blocking the way. This issue is political, phenomenological, physiological, sociological, and economic. These mediations don’t simply augment or preserve the real (that is, things, people, history, nature, etc.), they also erase connection to the real over time through an act of sublimation. Over time, models that are used frequently and authoritatively begin to sublimate into reality — we (the public) begin to take the model as truth, giving it precedence over the real in our ontological and epistemological standings. This is how many global standards come to be. This makes a lot of sense when you think about it — the more a model correctly predicts and fits the reality, the more we trust and internalize its predictions. But the rules and systems we make for ourselves replace our connection to reality by taking over some of our agency in order to ease our day-to-day existence. Infrastructure and ideology are not so different at all.

As a result, society's representation and experience of the world becomes static and disassociated from the world's real, active systems. I don't think we can fathom the degree to which artificial models have replaced our instinctual, embodied understanding of the world. The world is quickly being replaced by a technical model of itself. I don't go outside to check the weather anymore, I check my phone. I don't go into the forest anymore, I visit a well-maintained and socially engineered park. The world is losing its vital materialism, and the consequences of this are far-reaching: there are implications in all social, political, economic, environmental, and other spheres. Denying the vitality and agency of certain things and non-things in the world sets a dangerous precedent that has for ages been used as the organizational ideology for violent atrocities committed against minorities, nations, the earth, and the things we've produced. I understand now why Nietzsche wrote something along the lines of "I mistrust all systematizers and avoid them. The will to a system is a lack of integrity." (If you wish to know the exact source, you can look it up).

If we can't get rid of models and representation (I know we can't, and I know intuitively that we shouldn't): I want us to redefine the primitive concepts of models and representations. What does it really mean to represent something? How do we judge fidelity and authenticity and value? How do we retain a link between our artificial systems and the world's vital materialism? How do we augment the world transparently and organically rather than abstracting and erasing it through scientific canonicalization?

Lots of things need to change for this augmentation to happen, but here are a few: - We need to redefine what truth means in terms of human value systems — what does it mean to us, why do we search for it, do we really need all of it? - We need to find ways to bring our artificial systems and natural systems closer together. Hybrid systems are the only way forward. - We need to redefine at least the dominant Western ontology and restructure our way of categorizing the world into one that flattens hierarchy and recognizes intrinsic agency of matter.

This is a call for an ontology of presence, or a vital ontology. A new world of universal agency. An animated world.

But no revolution is coming. Not suddenly, anyways — more softly and spiritually, creeping in as culture evolves generation to generation. What we need is new generations of humans to adopt these ideas. To become closer to the earth and the human and the real. We need to bring vital materialism to social living and world building.

Vital materialism for me leads to dynamic ontologies that assume and defend the agency of all matter and non-matter (like ideas). Vital materialism also brings with it, for me, the essential idea that all things and non-things are connected. I believe that a vital materialism underlies all artifacts, systems, beings, activities, ideas, and spirits (by spirit here I mean something like history). Vitality is derived from being a contributing part of a dynamic system that enables the emergence and entropic decay of its parts. I know this is a broad definition, but it means that most things and beings have vital materialism and should be treated as such. This is like animism without the mysticism (forgive me if I misinterpret animism, I'm not extremely familiar).

The implications of evolving our social systems to adopt a vital materialist ontology and ideology are wide ranging and too complex for this single post, but I will say this much more: to create a more natural, engaged, real, joyful, and prosperous world, we need a revolution in materialism itself. Vital materialism yields vital politics, vital economics, a vital social, vital labor, vital study, vital living.

contents.content_html:
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet">I need an in-depth technical deconstruction of what it would take to suspend a virtual point 2cm above my left wrist at all times, for all eternity, no matter where i am, no matter how i move, no matter if I lose my hand/arm</p>— _.;-* (@edouerd) https://twitter.com/edouerd/status/1138532623461076992

Our constructs on top of reality, our interfaces — religions, governments, stock markets, software, sciences, mathematics — are mediations between us and the Real. They provide us models of the world, shot through with ideology, that help us 1) make sense of the world, 2) augment our lived experience, and 3) relieve us of the maintenance of social reality. While I think Edouard's tweet points to some other idea that I won't speculate about here, it uncovers the issue that our artificial constructs are unaware of the world's vital dynamism and materialism. Our constructs — the things, systems, and ideologies we construct — influence the world around them. Material things have networked impact. This is the cornerstone of Materialism.

But what Edouard's tweet got me thinking is that our artificial constructs can and should do a better job at adapting to and transparently augmenting our natural systems.

While I think Edouard's tweet points to some other idea that I won't speculate about here, it uncovers the issue that our artificial constructs are unaware of the world's vital dynamism and materialism. Our constructs — the things, systems, and ideologies we construct — influence the world around them. Material things have networked impact. This is the cornerstone of Materialism. But what Edouard's tweet got me thinking is that our artificial constructs can and should do a better job at adapting to and transparently augmenting our natural systems.

contents.content_html:
According to this definition, an ideology or idea has agency and vitality. This is perhaps a root of why the way we produce public policy is so problematic: it refuses to acknowledge the vitality of the written and enacted law, and of the things and people and ideas the law is intended to serve. The law is alive and interpreted in every enforcement and new policy introduction. The way we write policy, and the way we enable democracy for citizens through the voting system, denies the liquid nature of law and living in a society organized around the concept individual liberty. Laws are not rocks, they are small plants. The Law is not a tome, it is a tree.

To tie this back to representation and modeling: our laws make stagnant models and representations of the current state of our society. They are not linked directly enough to the actual, lived social reality. They freeze social state and make it effectively read-only. What we need is a system of distributed, individually-oriented policy-making (ahem direct liquid democracy) that empowers voters to make valuable decisions by providing them with

We need more direct and granular democracy for this, which will require new generations of voters with an ideology steeped in vital materialism. I know this is utopian, but I don’t see why this can’t begin slowly and turn into a larger global wave. Christianity began hyper-local, as an ideology and way of supporting each other. It evolved into a control apparatus over time (half emergently through the gospel's ties to colonialism and half due to the work of St. Paul the Apostle), but it also evolved globally into a multigenerational ideology. Its values became mostly canonical human "knowledge". I can see vital materialism following a similar path.

I think the internet (in 5–10 or so years, when we've fixed its rotten core) will enable the global distribution and adoption of vital and new materialist ideologies without requiring the colonialism that Christianity thrived on. I think these ideas — that everything and everyone has intrinsic agency, that systems are natural and need to adapt to their context, that models and representations need to work to reveal rather than replace their objects — will lead eventually to a turning over of our social, political, and economic values one, by one, by one. Vital materialism has everything to do with and tremendously supports efforts surrounding minority rights, open culture and authorship, identity politics, economics, mobility, citizenship, etc. Over time, enough vital materialists working in small, focused communities can infuse new values into the institutions that govern our society and culture. Political change today is possible only through direct work. (We need direct democracy in which every citizen is a policymaker and there is no policymaking class of citizens).

to reorganize a life around a recognition of the world's fundamental vitality

contents.title: test
contents.content_html:
let me restate my purpose here: to reorganize a life around a recognition of the world's fundamental vitality. what does this mean, exactly? there's a lot there.

to reorganize: to rebuild an ontology around, to organize one's activity around

a life: i guess the significance of including this is that it forces a connection between human activity on an individual scale and the world's vitality. i don't mean to say that human the vital world is centered around human activity; rather, i include this in order to situate the human being as the center of my study. this connection can be scaled to the size of populations easily, i think.

the world's fundamental vitality: the recognition of the world's materiality and the agency of material is not enough; in order to truly relate to the world in a fundamental way, we need to also recognize the "vitality" of material

contents.title: The Pixar Theory of Labor
contents.description_html: A lot of Pixar films come packaged with a quasi-humanist narrative hook that enables the public digestion of their work. Viewers nodded thoughtfully over WALL-E's depiction of a future earth choked by the refuse of big-box retail, and of a human race infantilized and rendered obese by mindless consumption, while Brave was the first Pixar film to feature a female protagonist - a simple gesture, the long-overdueness of which did not do very much to diminish murmurs of appreciation.

contents.title: Suspensions of Perception
contents.description_html: Suspensions of Perception decisively relocates the problem of aesthetic contemplation within a broader collective encounter with the unstable nature of perception-in psychology, philosophy, neurology, early cinema, and photography. metadata.description:
### A Slow, Invisible Death: The Necropolitics of Extractivism

Research for an essay tying together capitalistic extractivism and Achille Mbembe's necropolitics, arguing that the earth and those that depend on it have always already passed on and are perpetually in a state of life-as-death.

contents.title: Blackout: The Necropolitics of Extraction | Issue #001 | Dispatches Journal
contents.generated_title: Blackout: The Necropolitics of Extraction | Issue #001 | Dispatches Journal
contents.description_html: This essay addresses extraction, its visual cultures, as well as the politics and aesthetics of emergent forms of resistance today. In view of spreading sacrifice zones given over to resource mining, accompanied by exploitative international trade agreements and the finances of debt servitude, what forms do the cultural politics of opposition take, and how are artist-activists materializing the images and sounds of emancipation and decolonization against capitalism's rapacious commodification of anything and everything?

contents.content_html: “Marxist esthetics, which considers the work of art to be intimately related to social life as a whole, is left no choice with regard to the relation between content and form. It is forced to admit the priority of content, which then cretes the need for an appropriate form. Marxist aesthetics is therefore necessarily an aesthetics centered on content; and thus is situated at the opposite pole from all aesthetics based on a gratuitous or arbitrary play of forms and also from any sort of formalism.” (Henri Arvon, Marxist Esthetics, 41)

contents.title: Toward Materialist Aesthetics - Infinite Caesura
contents.description_html: We live in a world of images; there is nothing outside of the image. In recent centuries, the world has seen an accelerating proliferation of images, constantly under siege by their internal messages and the aesthetics that communicate them. Therefore, aesthetics are ground zero for praxis.
contents.description: We live in a world of images; there is nothing outside of the image. In recent centuries, the world has seen an accelerating proliferation of images, constantly under siege by their internal messages and the aesthetics that communicate them. Therefore, aesthetics are ground zero for praxis.

contents.generated_title: Probing Algorithmic Sovereignity and Datapower - Infinite Caesura
contents.description_html: Nation-state sovereignty is suffocating. Consequently the age of empirical, neoliberal politics is fast approaching its end. The following essay is an initial probe into the conditions that have enabled big tech companies to bring about the greatest global political transformation since the end of feudalism.
contents.description: Nation-state sovereignty is suffocating. Consequently the age of empirical, neoliberal politics is fast approaching its end. contents.title: The Aesthetics of Soft Automation - Infinite Caesura
contents.generated_title: The Aesthetics of Soft Automation - Infinite Caesura
contents.description_html: Automated technologies have always produced their own aesthetics of the machinery of work. With the rise of new media and digital technology, the aesthetics of automation have become something entirely different: encoded ideological signifiers with the sole goal of making us work more without noticing a shift in work hours or intensity.
contents.description: Automated technologies have always produced their own aesthetics of the machinery of work. With the rise of new media and digital technology, the aesthetics of automation have become something entirely different: encoded ideological signifiers with the sole goal of making us work more without noticing a shift in work hours or intensity.

Welcome to the Library of Practical and Conceptual Resources, a collaboration between The Creative Independent and Are.na.

metadata.description: Good Quotes

contents.content_html:
In summary, Deleuze tends to make concepts: 1) open-ended and inexhaustive, e.g. always have the potential to differ and grow despite a certain consistency of operation (Holland calls this the “underdetermination of concepts”); 2) non-exclusive and unlimited, e.g. every application is creative, generative, and an ongoing process and therefore always allows alternate routes to be taken, as in every actualization enables counter-actualizations (cf. Deleuze’s preference of potential to the possible); 3) exist in exteriority to one another and are therefore infinite, e.g. a general rule of Deleuze’s metaphysics is that the relation between two terms itself is a third term, so there is nothing “necessary” or “intrinsic,” only determinants within differing sizes of infinitely.

  • https://anarchistwithoutcontent.wordpress.com/2013/04/08/the-fold-explained/

"The idea behind deconstruction is to deconstruct the workings of strong nation-states with powerful immigration policies, to deconstruct the rhetoric of nationalism, the politics of place, the metaphysics of native land and native tongue… the idea is to disarm the bombs… of identity that nation-states build to defend themselves against the stranger, against Jews and Arabs and immigrants."

As quoted in: John D. Caputo, The Prayers and Tears of Jacques Derrida: Religion Without Religion, Indiana University Press, 1997, p. 231.

contents.content_html:
"the only weapon is rebellion and destruction, as the recently deceased apostle Jacques Derrida taught us. Wherever you see a window, throw into it a brick. Where there is a building, there must be a mine. Where there is a high-rise building, a bin Laden should come. Where there is any kind of institution, law or link, one should find a falsification, a ‘law’ of the street or of the underground"

Andrej Capuder, “Vino in most,” Demokracija, No. 50, year IX, Ljubljana, December 9 2004, p. 9 (translation mine).
contents.description_html: I disagree fundamentally with what the author says about Derrida, and think it is a terrible misinterpretation, but I like this quote anyways. I think it's emblematic of the type of creative rebellions necessary to dismantle the cartesian, hegemonic ontology we exist in today

contents.title: Ambient communities of knowledge
contents.content_html: In summary, rather than learning by replicating the performance of others or by acquiring knowledge transmitted in instruction, we suggest that learning occurs through centripetal participation in the learning curriculum of the ambient community. Because the place of knowledge is within a community of practice, questions of learning must be addressed within the developmental cycles of that community, a recommendation which creates a diagnostic tool for distinguishing among communities of practice.
contents.description_html: From Situated Learning: Legitimate Peripheral Participation (Wenger & Lave 1991)

metadata.description:
Part of my undergraduate thesis for the MICA Graphic Design program

There has never been reality since the emergence of conscious understanding. The first name a creature gave to a think was the deathblow to the thing-in-itself. Is there escape from this? What little moments of the real can we ascertain from our accelerating and expanding representational simulation of the world?

contents.content_html: As Virilio said, an age of speed—but not positive speed, negative speed. We look back further and longer, wishing for past ways of being, for the rapture of childhood, or the innocence of memory (why else is it that so many VR experiences, especially early ones, were so tinged with nostalgia?). Unable to return to this innocence, for we already know too much (knowledge must be answered to), we accelerate into simulacra, in search of something lost long ago: in search of ourselves.
contents.content: As Virilio said, an age of speed—but not positive speed, negative speed. We look back further and longer, wishing for past ways of being, for the rapture of childhood, or the innocence of memory (why else is it that so many VR experiences, especially early ones, were so tinged with nostalgia?). Unable to return to this innocence, for we already know too much (knowledge must be answered to), we accelerate into simulacra, in search of something lost long ago: in search of ourselves.

contents.content_html:
All our illusions today and through all of history have been for one purpose and one purpose alone: the trivial recreation of the childhood lapse (cf. Virilio, Aesthetics of Disappearance). Illusion is a pittance for the loss of the lapse of time and space, the momentary absence or flight from our material relations—ultimately, the loss of imagination.

An effort at reconciliation with oneself, or the loss of oneself (or what we perceive as the ultimate self: the self as child (cf. Nietzsche, Virilio, Freud, Guattari, etc etc and their obsession with the childlike).
contents.content:
All our illusions today and through all of history have been for one purpose and one purpose alone: the trivial recreation of the childhood lapse (cf. Virilio, *Aesthetics of Disappearance*). Illusion is a pittance for the loss of the lapse of time and space, the momentary absence or flight from our material relations—ultimately, the loss of imagination. 

An effort at reconciliation with oneself, or the loss of oneself (or what we perceive as the ultimate self: the self as child (cf. Nietzsche, Virilio, Freud, Guattari, etc etc and their obsession with the childlike).

contents.content_html: Our experience now is a bastardized version of the real, for the reward of our illusory systems feels more real to us than the cost of inescapable simulacra. We trade material reality for the illusion of speed, the Faustian pact of instant pleasure, of knowledge beyond knowing—we're living in a dream. Everything: faster, faster, all at once now; a world unmoored, left floating in a sea of absence. An infinite lapse of sense and sensibility. The bright white space of heaven and purgatory—sustained and unbreakable, never to be questioned or marred by the human act of thought—in place of the mixed and multicolor experience of the real. Perceptual clarity, technical optics, replacing the muddy and confusing experience of the real. Lost in abstractions—infinite abstractions—
contents.content: Our experience now is a bastardized version of the real, for the *reward* of our illusory systems feels more real to us than the *cost* of inescapable simulacra. We trade material reality for the illusion of speed, the Faustian pact of instant pleasure, of knowledge beyond knowing—we're living in a dream. Everything: faster, faster, all at once now; a world unmoored, left floating in a sea of absence. An infinite lapse of sense and sensibility. The bright white space of heaven and purgatory—sustained and unbreakable, never to be questioned or marred by the human act of thought—in place of the mixed and multicolor experience of the real. Perceptual clarity, technical optics, replacing the muddy and confusing experience of the real. Lost in abstractions—infinite abstractions—

contents.content_html: Illusion leads to total equilibrium, offsetting the weight of material reality with immaterial unreality. But what to do about uncontrolled illusion? We have entered this age, an age of complete absence, man is no longer present in the world (cf. Virilio—not a machine world, as he described, but an illusion-world; not of speed but of infinite slowness, experience in a vacuum, time itself slowed to a halt). We have entered an age of abuse, of illusion whose treasures have become inexhaustible. We never cease to be enraptured by the introduction of new fidelities of illusion—new phones, new cameras, new realities, new gods to replace the old.
contents.content: Illusion leads to total equilibrium, offsetting the weight of material reality with immaterial unreality. But what to do about uncontrolled illusion? We have entered this age, an age of complete absence, man is no longer present in the world (cf. Virilio—not a machine world, as he described, but an illusion-world; not of speed but of infinite slowness, experience in a vacuum, time itself slowed to a halt). We have entered an age of abuse, of illusion whose treasures have become inexhaustible. We never cease to be enraptured by the introduction of new fidelities of illusion—new phones, new cameras, new realities, new gods to replace the old.

contents.content_html: In illusion we find "a knowledge whose treasure becomes inexhaustible" (Lyotard). The opiate, the narcotic, the myth, Dionysian—all illusions, all intended to lend us a glimpse of another world—a world that does not belong to us, that belongs to no one: a world of nothing. When Plato spoke of metaphysical dualism he spoke of this but did not know it: the world of disembodied illusion, the world we should not access (lest we become lost in it).
contents.content: In illusion we find "a knowledge whose treasure becomes inexhaustible" (Lyotard). The opiate, the narcotic, the myth, Dionysian—all illusions, all intended to lend us a glimpse of another world—a world that does not belong to us, that belongs to no one: a world of nothing. When Plato spoke of metaphysical dualism he spoke of this but did not know it: the world of disembodied illusion, the world we should not access (lest we become lost in it).

contents.content_html: How do illusions break down, abstract, or otherwise obscure our material relations? How do they force us to forget for a moment something so vital to our phenomenological sensing? The seizure, the picnoleptic lapse (cf. Virilio)—these things also remove us momentarily from our material relations (time, also, is a material—perhaps even the purest form of all). In illusion we are disembodied, free of material constraints even for just a glimmer of rapturous, illusory, borderline-narcotic experience. But these moments myst always pass. The material demands to be acknowledged.

The seizure, the picnoleptic lapse (cf. Virilio)—these things also remove us momentarily from our material relations (time, also, is a material—perhaps even the purest form of all). In illusion we are disembodied, free of material constraints even for just a glimmer of rapturous, illusory, borderline-narcotic experience. But these moments myst always pass. The material demands to be acknowledged.

contents.content_html:
More generally, it’s not beginnings and ends that count, but middles. Things and thoughts advance or grow out from the middle, and that’s where you have to get to work, that’s where everything unfolds.

– Gilles Deleuze, On Leibniz

contents.content_html:
performative portfolio—different portfolio sites for each type of work you do, each with its own emergent style, narrative, character, tone, and identity

(this comes from the realization that as a multi(trans-?)disciplinary person, each deep skillset I possess requires its own sort of narrativization and identity in order to sustain that practice—it's tough if not impossible to merge my conceptual design practice's identity expression with my product design identity, or my commercial product design identity with my artist identity)

(how do I wish to present myself as a product designer, to product design clients? or a graphic designer, to graphic design clients? or an artist, to artists or gallerists? or a photographer, to whoever the hell likes photography? or a sculptor, to weird people? or a poet, to sensitive folks? or a philosopher, to publishers?)

contents.content_html: once again: how fucking insane is it that we've taken the earth, raised it to the surface, transfigured it into apparatuses of control, and made the very earth appear heavier, dirtier, more burdensome? there has ostensibly been no weight added—only weight displaced. we've made this planet into a burden.

contents.content_html:
the way the earth feels heavy—
we have made it burdensome.
a little trickery, magic by deception.
a great inversion, grand theft.
give it all back.
not a gift, just reparation.

the earth was meant to be experienced lightly, a blade of grass, a little river, a raging hurricane: these things, even in varying intensity, remain light

in our digging, we have populated the earth with itself—devices, couches, buildings, socks, straws, plastic bags, clothes, tables, machines (many for digging). these things are rocks, metals, clays, oils, gasses, sands and deep times

the earth is in effect, displaced -> the earth is, in effect, displaced

its blood floating congealed in the oceans, skin torn and blemished, bones crunched and taken for pharmakon, even its own apparatus captured by a foreign logic

contents.content_html:
In any reasonably complex problem these misfits are interrelated — mediated by common considerations — and a design must make appropriate tradeoffs when misfits conflict. For example, a kettle needs to heat up quickly yet keep its water hot for a sufficient period of time, and these requirements (i.e. potential misfits) depend on the properties of the material used in construction. Perhaps the most common design tradeoff is that of expense: the lower bound on quality of materials conflicts with the upper bound on price of the resultant product.

The unselfconscious process produces good fit slowly through selective pressures, yet we don’t have the luxury of waiting generations to solve modern problems, and many problems are simply too complex to be solved by blind search.

Sets of interdependent misfits can be thought of as a graph, a now-common data structure. Alexander observes that when the graph consists of loosely interconnected clusters of strongly interconnected misfits we have some chance of finding a solution. When the graph is fully connected — every misfit affects every other misfit — solutions are nearly unobtainable.

(https://medium.com/@hyponymous/notes-on-notes-on-the-synthesis-of-form-5327aa6ff6a1)

contents.content_html:
what makes up Muji's aesthetic? what does their aesthetic tell us about their production process?

muji has a rather pleasing minimalist aesthetic (need better description lmao wtf), but does it arise from aesthetic vision or from production cost mediation? many products appear high quality, durable, and well-made, but upon closer inspection, they only have the appearance of these things (aside from their clothing, I think). this, in light of the questions asked at the outset of this thought, that part of muji's aesthetic framework is tied to production cost efficiency. (need to do a lot of research for this one)

further—what other aesthetics are the results of market forces, or more specifically the market forces involved in production?

objects: muji (cost limiting), apple (cost embracing?), target-owned brands (cost-mediating?)
software: early macOS & Windows (cost-limiting?); late macOS & Windows (cost-embracing), airbnb (cost-mediating? or cost-embracing????); most other apps (cost-mediating, though not always on purpose)

contents.content_html: These explicit rules are lossy, whereas models learned through trial and error are incredibly rich and detailed, and fit the territory better than explicitly learned models. While comparatively easy to communicate, explicit models need their lacunae filled in through experience before they become useful. Intuitive trial-and-error learning tends to rely heavily on context, is difficult to transmit, and may even present barriers to introspection and self-awareness. (https://medium.com/@hyponymous/notes-on-notes-on-the-synthesis-of-form-5327aa6ff6a1)

contents.content_html: …the aesthetics of automation are not merely a cause of the amount people work today, but are also an effect of an underlying interplay of forces and powers, including the painful state of rapidly increasing amounts of work that catalyzed the need for automated technologies in the first place. These aesthetics, in fact, are a semiotic representation of, and vessel for the execution of, a new type of power being exerted over populations in an ultimate, even if unconscious, effort to make humans harder working, more docile, and more replaceable.

contents.description_html: A Pyrrhic victory PIRR-ik) is a victory that inflicts such a devastating toll on the victor that it is tantamount to defeat. Someone who wins a Pyrrhic victory has been victorious in some way, though the heavy toll negates a true sense of achievement or profit.

contents.title: Calm technology | Wikiwand
contents.description_html: Calm technology is a type of information technology where the interaction between the technology and its user is designed to occur in the user's periphery rather than constantly at the center of attention. Information from the technology smoothly shifts to the user's attention when needed but otherwise stays calmly in the user's periphery.

contents.title: Isotropy | Wikiwand
contents.description_html: Isotropy is uniformity in all orientations; it is derived from the Greek isos and tropos . Precise definitions depend on the subject area. Exceptions, or inequalities, are frequently indicated by the prefix an, hence anisotropy. Anisotropy is also used to describe situations where properties vary systematically, dependent on direction.

contents.title: Waterbed theory | Wikiwand
contents.description_html: Waterbed theory is the observation, ascribed to Larry Wall, that some systems, such as human and computer languages, contain a minimum amount of complexity, and that attempting to "push down" the complexity of such a system in one place will invariably cause complexity to "pop up" elsewhere.
